Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Revealing the genomic targets of opposing natural selection that differ between females and males
Award.AbstractNarration:
Males and females of the same species share a genome and express many of the same traits. However, the two sexes often experience dramatic differences in natural selection on these shared traits. This can create an evolutionary tug-of-war when a trait and its underlying genes are beneficial in one sex, but detrimental in the other. This study will investigate this selection conflict in brown anole lizards. Such conflict can occur in any species with separate sexes and is predicted to have important implications for the evolution of differences between males and females, systems of sex determination, and the maintenance of genetic variation. The researchers will genetically sequence individuals from a wild population with extreme sex differences to identify genomic regions that are subject to this selection conflict. In addition, this project will provide research training for undergraduate students and the research will be used as the basis for developing field-tested educational materials designed to build skills for data interpretation in the K-12 classroom.

Despite its implications for so many major questions in biology, sexual conflict has rarely been demonstrated in wild populations, and we have yet to identify the actual regions of the genome that are subject to sexual conflict in natural populations. This project has three aims: (1) test for sex differences in natural selection on a variety of traits, (2) test for fitness costs of sexual conflict by measuring the extent to which the genetic basis of fitness is correlated between males and females, and (3) combine field estimates of fitness with large-scale genomic data and powerful statistical methods to uncover genomic regions associated with sexual conflict in a wild population of brown anole lizards (Anolis sagrei). This work is being conducted using an island population of more than a thousand adult lizards that is highly amenable to large-scale studies of natural selection. The researchers will use their data to test whether the same genomic regions contribute to fitness in each sex, to measure the extent to which these genes are subject to sex differences in selection, and to determine which components of fitness (survival, reproductive success) give rise to intralocus sexual conflict.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Males and females of the same species share a genome and thus the genetic basis for shared traits is often the same for both sexes. However, natural selection often acts differently on the same trait in each sex. This results in a genomic conflict in which genes that are detrimental to one sex are maintained because they are beneficial to the other sex. Such sexual conflict is likely widespread in sexually reproducing species, has potential implications for the independent evolution of males and females, and may be an important mechanism that maintaines genetic diversity in natural populations. Despite, the potential for this type of genomic conflict to influence the evolutionary trajectory of all sexual species, sexual conflict has only rarely been demonstrated in natural populations and it remains an open question as to which traits and components of fitness drive sexual conflict of this nature. 

Intellectual Merit: We conducted a large-scale field study using a wild population of the lizard Anolis sagrei to test for sexual conflict in a natural population. Using mark and recapture over 4 years, we tracked the survival of and estimated natural selection on a suite of traits for a closed population on a single island over four generations. The resulting dataset consists of phenotypic and survival data for more than 6,000 individuals that were observed from their season of hatching to death. We found that the rise of sexually antagonistic selection on body size during the first year of life coincides with the onset of sexual maturity. Additionally, we observed selection acting against growth rate; growth rate following hatching was correlated with a decreased chance of overwinter survival. Funds from this award were also used to develop a panel of over 200 loci for the Genotyping-in-Thousands by sequencing (GT-seq) pipeline. Work is underway to sequence DNA from more than 6,000 individuals from the study with this GT-seq panel and build a population pedigree. This pedigree will be used to test whether genetic variance for male fitness is negatively correlated with genetic variation for female fitness, which is the gold standard for detecting sexual conflict. 

Broader impacts: This award assisted two undergraduate students in conducting independent research over two academic years and summer field seasons. Additionally, this grant resulted in a collaboration between these undergraduate students and four high school teachers to produce educational materials designed to improve the quantitative skills of K-12 science students. This collaboration produced two sets of curricular materials widely available on the NSF-supported Data Nuggets website. These materials share the story behind the science and can be used in K-12 classrooms to teach natural selection with a quantitative approach, as well as graphing and data skills. All of the resulting materials are freely available to K-12 teachers and have been accessed 376 times on datanuggets.com since their online publication in October 2017.
